The patient's recent onset of eye redness, swelling, and tearing after playing soccer suggests an infectious process likely due to local skin trauma. The severity seems mild to moderate given the short duration and absence of systemic symptoms or visual changes. Immediate urgent care is warranted to prevent progression, especially since orbital cellulitis must be differentiated and ruled out. Differential considerations include bacterial conjunctivitis, allergic conjunctivitis, or a skin abscess.  Evidence-based management involves prompt antimicrobial therapy, supportive care, and close follow-up. Antibiotics targeting common pathogens (Staphylococcus and Streptococcus species) are first-line. Since preseptal cellulitis typically responds well to antibiotics without hospitalization unless signs of orbital involvement or systemic illness develop, outpatient management is preferred with strict monitoring. Further assessment should include checking for visual acuity, eye motility, and signs of orbital cellulitis to rule out more serious complications.
